name: p-dinitrobenzene
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.
Reason: 1,2,3-Trinitro compounds have a melting point influenced by functional groups relative to benzene's melting point of 5.5 °C. The basic unit we can compare to is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The additional functional groups and structural features in p-dinitrobenzene will affect its melting point: (1) Two phenyl groups, which could each add approximately +20 due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure; (2) The tertiary butyl group (C(C)C) is a bulky group which could add about +10 due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume; (3) The piperidine ring (N1CCCC1) and 1-ethyl-4-methylenepiperidine moiety may both add roughly +20 each due to adding more rigid ring structures and making the molecule more compact; (4) The dinitro group introduces two strong withdrawing groups, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50 degrees Celsius. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
